Award.AwardTitle: Mobile Gait Analysis via Low-power Piezoresponsive Wearable Sensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The way that we move has long been recognized as a window into human health; our gait is affected by numerous pathologies, including arthritis, diabetes, and Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases. Having access to quantitative gait analysis could be an important tool for pathology prevention, diagnosis, and management. However to date, quantitative gait analysis has been largely confined to the laboratory, due to the cumbersome and expensive nature of multi-camera motion tracking lab equipment. This project uses novel sensors that employ materials that emit a voltage when subjected to mechanical stress and has the objective of bringing mobile gait analysis to the general public, in their real-world environment. These wearable sensors are inexpensive, consume little power, and can wirelessly communicate with a nearby smartphone. In addition, the sensor technology itself promises to be transformational across a broad cross-section of applications including clothing-integrated wearable sensors, self-sensing furniture, smart mounts for vibrating equipment, advanced airbag deployment systems, integrated helmet concussion sensors and self-sensing shoes. Students from both mechanical engineering and exercise sciences are intimately involved in all aspects of the research to provide a unique cross-disciplinary educational environment. Furthermore, high school students can apply to receive gait analysis systems to solve interesting science and technology problems.

The piezoresponsive nano-composite sensors used in this project are comprised of a dielectric polymer matrix impregnated with a network of conductive nano-particles. The mechanical and electrical responses of the sensors are independently tailored to provide an optimized system for multifunctional implementation in numerous systems requiring large-deflection sensing capabilities. When connected to a voltage-sensing device (for example, a blue-tooth transmitting Arduino microcomputer) the sensors can track deformation and impact energy and relay it to a nearby smartphone. In order to effectively leverage these sensors for mobile gait analysis, several scientific barriers need to be overcome. The piezoresponse of the sensors will be modeled using a machine-learning algorithm to enable accurate, continuous self-calibration of the sensors. An optimized mesh network of sensors will be designed to allow mobile gait analysis and will be validated against traditional gait lab instruments. Finally, the optimized sensors will be utilized to measure gait in a cross-section of subjects to establish a public baseline database of gait behavior in a variety of real-life environments (i.e., outside of the laboratory).

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The way that we move has long been recognized as a window into human health. Bipedal locomotion is uniquely challenging from a control standpoint, and is sensitive to numerous factors, including mood, pain, current or previous musculoskeletal injury, neural deficits, vision distortion, vestibular dysfunction, and various other pathologies, even including some types of cancer.  Interestingly, each of these factors manifests itself uniquely in our gait; making gait analysis a valuable diagnostic tool with a specificity that rivals or exceeds our current capabilities in terms of pathological diagnostics (e.g., blood tests or medical imaging) for many conditions.  Unfortunately, our current ability to leverage the available information from human gait is limited by our sensing capabilities.  Gait analysis requires accurate measurement of both limb motion and ground reaction forces during locomotion, currently requiring a multi-camera motion tracking lab with an integrated force plate or instrumented treadmill.  The cost of such a lab can easily exceed several hundred thousand dollars.  During the course of this project, we characterized, modeled, and implemented novel nanocomposite sensors to bring mobile gait analysis to the general public as a low-cost, low-power wearable technology. 

Intellectual Merit: The present work has reduced the cost of the traditional gait laboratory by three orders of magnitude (approximate sensor and hardware cost of ~$100).  Additionally these sensors were characterized under a broad range of environmental and mechanical use conditions.  The sensors were used to accurately measure gait parameters (ground reaction forces, energy expenditure, joint angles) in a variety of real-world conditions. The completed work provided advancements in calibration of viscoelastic sensors using machine learning algorithms, and transferred recent advancements in localized distributed networking to a novel Bluetooth sensor application. Overall, the work resulted in 22 peer reviewed journal articles and conference papers, 10 additional conference presentations, 1 patent, 4 MS theses, and 1 PhD dissertation.

Broader Impacts:  The same sensors are now being directly applied to all types of motion analysis by out team at BYU, as well as researchers at Columbia University, Virginia Tech University, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and Sun Yat-sen University in Guangzhou, China. Additionally, these sensor technologies have been licensed from the university and are being developed for commercial application as clothing-integrated wearable sensors to track fetal activity, measure impact and predict concussion risk, and even in smart mattresses. Students from mechanical engineering, exercise science, and statistics were intimately involved in all aspects of the research project, including dissemination of the results.  The project involved 4 faculty researchers, 9 graduate students, and 13 undergraduate students who participated in the project. 21/22 students were involved in at least publication associated with the project.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2018
Modified by: Anton Bowden

Position-specific sensor voltage signals from each sensor during walking gait for three different subjects for 5 different stance periods, as well as the measured vertical ground reaction forces measured from a traditional force
    Lee, J, Li G, Christensen WF, Collins G, Seeley MK, Bowden AE, Fullwood DT, Goldsmith J (2018), ?Functional data analyses of gait data measured using in-shoe sensors,? Statistics in Biosciences, doi: https://doi.org/10.1007/s12561-018-9226-3

  • Force-platform measured vertical ground reaction forces (left) for 3 different subjects during walking gait for three different subjects for 5 different stance periods, as well as the predicted values (center) and residuals (right) based on the sensor model predictions.
    Lee, J, Li G, Christensen WF, Collins G, Seeley MK, Bowden AE, Fullwood DT, Goldsmith J (2018), ?Functional data analyses of gait data measured using in-shoe sensors,? Statistics in Biosciences, doi: https://doi.org/10.1007/s12561-018-9226-3

    Rosquist PG, Collins G, Merrell AJ, Tuttle NJ, Tracy JB, Bird ET, Seeley MK, Fullwood DT, Christensen WF, Bowden AE (2017). Estimation of 3D Ground Reaction Force using Nanocomposite Piezo-Responsive Foam Sensors during Walking, Annals of Biomedical Engineering, 45(9):2122-2134.
    Copyrighted

    Figure 3
  • A comparison of error biases between predicted energy expenditure, at various ambulation ?speeds, predicted using the NCPF foam sensor equipped shoes (Left, NCPF Shoes), and (2) a commercially available devices that are used to predict energy expenditure as reported in published literature.
    Evans A, Collins G, Rosquist P, Tuttle N, Morrin SJ, Tracy J, Merrell AJ, Christensen WF, Fullwood DT, Bowden AE, Seeley MK (2018), Predicting energy expenditure during walking and running using novel piezoelectric foam sensors. Journal for the Measurement of Physical Behavior

B) VICON measured sagittal knee angle (solid black) and nanocomposite strain gauge model prediction (dotted red) at three speeds and three inclinations. C) Root-mean square error for discrete gait parameters across all speeds and inclines
    Adin Martineau

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The way that we move has long been recognized as a window into human health. Bipedal locomotion is uniquely challenging from a control standpoint, and is sensitive to numerous factors, including mood, pain, current or previous musculoskeletal injury, neural deficits, vision distortion, vestibular dysfunction, and various other pathologies, even including some types of cancer. Interestingly, each of these factors manifests itself uniquely in our gait; making gait analysis a valuable diagnostic tool with a specificity that rivals or exceeds our current capabilities in terms of pathological diagnostics (e.g., blood tests or medical imaging) for many conditions. Unfortunately, our current ability to leverage the available information from human gait is limited by our sensing capabilities. Gait analysis requires accurate measurement of both limb motion and ground reaction forces during locomotion, currently requiring a multi-camera motion tracking lab with an integrated force plate or instrumented treadmill. The cost of such a lab can easily exceed several hundred thousand dollars. During the course of this project, we characterized, modeled, and implemented novel nanocomposite sensors to bring mobile gait analysis to the general public as a low-cost, low-power wearable technology. Intellectual Merit: The present work has reduced the cost of the traditional gait laboratory by three orders of magnitude (approximate sensor and hardware cost of ~$100). Additionally these sensors were characterized under a broad range of environmental and mechanical use conditions. The sensors were used to accurately measure gait parameters (ground reaction forces, energy expenditure, joint angles) in a variety of real-world conditions. The completed work provided advancements in calibration of viscoelastic sensors using machine learning algorithms, and transferred recent advancements in localized distributed networking to a novel Bluetooth sensor application. Overall, the work resulted in 22 peer reviewed journal articles and conference papers, 10 additional conference presentations, 1 patent, 4 MS theses, and 1 PhD dissertation. Broader Impacts: The same sensors are now being directly applied to all types of motion analysis by out team at BYU, as well as researchers at Columbia University, Virginia Tech University, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and Sun Yat-sen University in Guangzhou, China. Additionally, these sensor technologies have been licensed from the university and are being developed for commercial application as clothing-integrated wearable sensors to track fetal activity, measure impact and predict concussion risk, and even in smart mattresses. Students from mechanical engineering, exercise science, and statistics were intimately involved in all aspects of the research project, including dissemination of the results. The project involved 4 faculty researchers, 9 graduate students, and 13 undergraduate students who participated in the project. 21/22 students were involved in at least publication associated with the project.
